title-group.article-title: Environmental Factors in the First Trimester and Risk of Oral-Facial Clefts in the Offspring

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Obstetrics & Gynaecology, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Prince of Wales Hospital, Hong Kong, Hong Kong
2Division of Occupational and Environmental Health, School of Public Health and Primary Care, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong

author-notes.corresp: Terence T Lao, Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Prince of Wales Hospital, Shatin, Hong Kong, Hong Kong Email: lao-tt@cuhk.edu.hk

abstract.p: The averaged incidences of nonsyndromal/isolated cleft lip (CL), cleft palate (CP), and cleft lip with cleft palate (CLCP) by each month-of-conception, and managed in our hospital in from 2002 to 2009 were correlated with the reported levels of sunshine, ultraviolet radiation, and ambient nitrogen oxides (nitrogen oxide, nitrogen monoxide, and nitrogen dioxide), sulfur dioxide, and ozone, at the month of, and then at 4 and 8 weeks after, conception. There were 25, 12, and 22 cases each of CL, CP, and CLCP, respectively, totaling 59 cases (1.21 of 1000 births). On regression analysis, sunshine correlated inversely with the isolated CL at (P = .009) 4 weeks (P = .005) and 8 weeks (P = .008) postconception, and with CP (P = .009) and CLCP (P < .001) at 8 weeks postconception, while NOx correlated inversely with CL (P = .018) and NO with CLCP (P = .031), at 8 weeks postconception. Our results suggested that the interaction between sunshine and nitrogen oxides with other factors results in the reported seasonal variation in the incidence of isolated oral-facial clefts.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
One of the commonest nonlethal structural malformations affecting newborn infants worldwide is oral-facial clefts, including isolated cleft lip (CL), isolated cleft palate (CP), and cleft lip with cleft palate (CLCP). The etiology of oral-facial clefts remains uncertain and various factors have been suggested in the literature. These include growth factors such as transforming growth factor α (TGFA) and transforming growth factor β3 (TGFB3), transcription factors such as MSX1, 1RF6, and TBX22, factors related to xenobiotic and nutrient metabolism and immune responses, 1 maternal smoking, 2 and consumption of drugs and alcohol 3,4 during pregnancy. However, none of these factors could account for the observed seasonal variations in the incidence of oral-facial clefts worldwide. 1,5
–11 We reported earlier 12 that the incidence of isolated nonsyndromal oral-facial clefts was highest in winter and lowest in autumn and suspected that seasonal factors could have played a role. One of these factors is the duration of the available sunlight, which is shortest in winter/spring and longest in summer/autumn. However, the amount of available sunlight at each geographical location cannot provide an adequate explanation of the differences in the incidences of oral-facial clefts in locations situated at different latitudes in the northern hemisphere, which were between 1.4 of 1000 births and 2.0 of 1000 births from Philippines 13 and Thailand 14 to Korea 15 and Japan. 5,16 Therefore, environmental pollutants 17,18 could have played a hitherto unrecognized but important etiological or contributory role.

Hong Kong is a highly urbanized city with an area of only 1076 km2, a highly homogeneous southern Chinese population, no agricultural or manufacturing industry or solid waste incinerators, a well-organized public obstetric service with prenatal diagnosis available to all local residents, and a Government Environmental Protection Department (EPD) which monitors and reports on the available sunlight and ultraviolet radiation (UVR), and concentrations of common air pollutants including the nitrogen oxide compounds (nitrogen oxide [NOx], nitrogen monoxide [NO], and nitrogen dioxide [NO2]), sulfur dioxide (SO2), and ozone (O3). Therefore, Hong Kong is an ideal place to conduct a study on the relationship between environmental factors, the information on which is readily available, with the occurrence of oral-facial clefts, as there is no way that the local residents could escape from the exposure to sunlight or to ambient air pollutants in their everyday life. This retrospective ecological study was therefore performed to re-examine the relationship between the seasonal variations in the incidence of oral-facial clefts we reported previously 12 with the monthly averaged sunshine, UVR, and concentrations of ambient air pollutants as reported in the Government EPD website over the same period, to determine whether these environmental factors could have been responsible.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Our hospital is a university teaching hospital and regional referral center with a prenatal diagnosis clinic (PDC) under the Fetal Medicine Team. Regular statistics and audits have been conducted since 2002, when a database was established. For this ecological study, we analyzed the cases of oral-facial clefts diagnosed from January 2002 to December 2009 as recorded in the PDC database. These included cases missed antenatally but diagnosed after birth or abortion, when a complete systematic examination was performed for all the infants. For the purpose of this study, syndromal cases and those with chromosomal abnormalities, as recorded in the database, were excluded from the final analysis. The expected date of confinement for each case was used to place the individual cases among total deliveries for each calendar month so as to calculate the monthly rate and then we worked backward to derive the estimated time of conception so as to constitute the conception cohorts for each month. In order to smooth out fluctuations, we used a 3-month sliding window calculation method described before, 9 and which was used in our previous study. 12 The cases in the adjacent 3 months-clusters were averaged (January = December to February/3, June = May to July/3, December = November to January/3, etc), and the average number of cases was divided by the total number of deliveries to produce the final month-of-conception cohorts for the assessment of seasonality. The initial analysis indicating a significant seasonal variation in the incidence of oral-facial clefts has been published earlier. 12 To explore the role of environmental factors, further analysis on the relationship with environmental factors was performed in this ecological study.

To explore the relationship between the incidence of oral-facial clefts with available sunlight reported as level of sunshine, UVR, and ambient air pollutants, the rate of oral-facial clefts for each calendar month of conception and in 4 and 8 weeks after conception was correlated (Pearson correlation) with the averaged monthly levels of sunshine, UVR, NOx, NO, NO2, SO2, and O3, as reported by the EPD in the official website (http://www.epd.gov.hk) on the month of conception and at 4 and 8 weeks postconception over the same period. This is because the development and fusion process of the lips and palate starts from the fourth week and is completed by the tenth week of human embryonic development, 19 so that analysis in this way could explore the impact of these environmental factors over the entire period when fusion of the lips and palate takes place. Statistical analysis was performed using a commercial package SPSS 17.0 (SPSS Inc, Chicago, Illinois), and a P value <.05 was regarded as statistically significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: There were 48 804 deliveries during the period January 2002 to December 2009 in the department and 59 cases of isolated oral-facial clefts were recorded, including 41 (69.5%) live births and 18 (30.5%) therapeutic abortions. The 59 cases accounted for 54.1% (59 of 109) of the total cases of oral-facial clefts diagnosed during this period. The actual number of cases seen per year ranged from 3 to 12, while the rate varied from 0.59 to 1.80 per 1000 births, with an overall rate of 1.21 per 1000 births. Of these 59 cases, 25 (42.4%) were isolated CL (0.51 per 1000 births), 12 (20.3%) were isolated CP (0.25 per 1000 births), and 22 (37.3%) were CLCP (0.45 per 1000 births).

The averaged monthly number of cases of oral-facial clefts during the study period and the total monthly deliveries are shown in Figure 1 and the calculated monthly incidences of oral-facial clefts are shown in Figure 2. The highest incidence was 1.96 of 1000 births in February, while the lowest incidence was 0.67 of 1000 births in September. When the averaged monthly mean (±standard error of the mean) values of sunshine, UVR, and the ambient air pollutants for the period 2002 to 2009 are analyzed, significant difference in the mean monthly levels of all these parameters was observed (P < .001, Table 1). When the monthly rate of oral-facial clefts was correlated with the corresponding levels of these environmental parameters at conception, significant correlation was found with sunshine (r = −.788, P = .002), NOx (r = .685, P = .014), and NO (r = .750, P = .005). There was no correlation with UVR (r = −.450, P = .142), NO2 (r = .234, P = .464), SO2 (r = .054, P = .867), or O3 (r = −.354, P = .259).

caption.p: Monthly number of oral-facial clefts and deliveries during the study period, 2002 to 2009.
Monthly incidences of oral-facial clefts during the study period, 2002 to 2009.
The Monthly Mean (±SEM) Value of Pollutant Concentrations From 2002 to 2009 as Reported by the Hong Kong Environmental Protection Department

fn.p: Abbreviations: NOx, nitrogen oxide; NO, nitrogen monoxide; NO2, nitrogen dioxide; O3,ozone; SO2, sulfur dioxide; UVR, ultraviolet radiation.

sec.p: Since different underlying mechanisms might have accounted for different malformations, each group of malformation was then analyzed individually with sunshine, NOx, and NO, which were shown in the initial analysis to be significant factors. As the development and fusion process of the lips and palate starts from the fourth week and is completed by the tenth week of human embryonic development, 19 the levels of these environmental factors at the month of and at 4 and 8 weeks postconception were correlated with the rate of the individual malformation by month-of-conception cohorts in order to cover the period from the fourth to the tenth week of the first trimester (Table 2). For isolated CL, significant inverse correlation was found with sunshine at the month of conception (r = −.802, P = .002), while the correlation with NOx (r = .554, P = .061) and NO (r = .561, P = .057) just failed to reach statistical significance. Significant inverse correlation was maintained with sunshine at 4 weeks (r = −.829, P = .001) and 8 weeks (r = −.693, P = .012) postconception, but the correlation with NOx and NO failed to reach statistical significance. For isolated CP, the only significant correlation was with NO at conception (r = .647, P = .023) and there was significant but borderline inverse correlation with NOx (r = −.596, P = .041) and NO (r = −.585, P = .046) at 8 weeks postconception. For combined CLCP, the incidence was positively correlated with NOx (r = .789, P = .002) and NO (r = .803, P = .002) at conception. There was no correlation with any parameter at 4 weeks postconception, but, there was an inverse correlation with sunshine at 8 weeks postconception (r = −.738, P = .006).

caption.p: Correlation Between Environmental Factors With the Incidence of Oral-Facial Clefts at and 4 and 8 Weeks After Conceptiona

fn.p: Abbreviations: NOx, nitrogen oxide; NO, nitrogen monoxide.
a Results are expressed as Pearson r and P value. Significant correlation is shown in bold.

sec.p: In order to determine the independent relationship between isolated CL, isolated CP, and isolated CLCP with sunshine, NOx, and NO, linear regression analysis was performed between these parameters at conception, at 4 weeks, and 8 weeks postconception with each individual malformation (Table 3). Sunshine was the only significant factor for oral-facial clefts overall (P = .006). For isolated CL, significant inverse correlation was found with sunshine at conception (P = .009), and at 4 weeks (P = .005) and 8 weeks (P = .008) postconception as well as with NOx at 8 weeks postconception (P = .018), while no significant correlation was found with NO. For isolated CP, only sunshine at 8 weeks postconception showed a significant correlation (P = .009), while no correlation with NOx or NO was found. For isolated CLCP, the only significant correlation was an inverse correlation with sunshine (P < .001) and with NO (P = .031) at 8 weeks postconception.

caption.p: Linear Regression Analysis of the Environmental Factors at and 4 and 8 Weeks After Conception With the Incidence of Oral-Facial Cleftsa

fn.p: Abbreviations: NOx, nitrogen oxide; NO, nitrogen monoxide.
a Results are expressed as correlation (β) and P value. Significant correlation is shown in bold.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
In this study, our observed the incidence of 1.209 of 1000 births for nonsyndromal oral-facial clefts was similar to that reported in China (1.20/1000 births), Japan (1.18/1000 births), and other Asian countries (1.22/1000 births). 5 As nonchromosomal malformations essentially arise from insults in the first trimester, and birth defects tend to be associated with reduced gestation length, 20 our use of the date of conception approach to calculate a pooled monthly conception rate 9 to evaluate the relationship between oral-facial clefts with environmental factors documented for the critical period of the fourth to the tenth week of gestation when fusion of the lips and palate occur 19 would allow us to explore the possibility of sequential effects of these factors. We found a correlation between the averaged monthly levels of sunshine, NOx, and NO, with the monthly incidence of oral-facial clefts found. Specifically, averaged sunshine at conception and 4 and 8 weeks postconception was inversely correlated with the incidence of isolated CL, while that at 8 weeks postconception was inversely correlated with isolated CP and isolated CLCP. For NOx, there was only an inverse correlation for the mean level at 8 weeks postconception with isolated CL, while likewise NO at 8 weeks postconception showed an inverse correlation with isolated CLCP. Our results, therefore, suggested that the formation of oral-facial clefts are likely to be consequent to the interaction of a number of environmental factors operating throughout the first trimester, and which tend largely to reduce the risk of oral-facial clefts, especially isolated CL, through some form of mitigating effect on other teratogenic factors that could include any or most of the factors described before, such as TGFA and TGFB3, MSX1, 1RF6, TBX22, factors related to xenobiotic and nutrient metabolism and immune responses, 1 maternal smoking, 2 and consumption of drugs and alcohol 3,4 during pregnancy. In the literature, ambient air pollutants have been associated with adverse obstetric outcome such as low birth weight, 21,22 intrauterine growth restriction, 23 –25 preterm delivery, 25 –27 and certain congenital anomalies such as the increase in mainly cardiovascular anomalies with exposure to elevated carbon monoxide (CO), O3, particulate matter <10 μmol/L (PM10), and SO2 levels. 28
–31 For nonsyndromal oral-facial clefts, this relationship remains unclear, as it was reported to increase with increasing proximity to the municipal solid waste incinerator, 32 to have no relationship with traffic exposure 32 as well as being linked to outdoor O3. 33 Taken together, the most likely reason for the conflicting literature and the largely futile attempts in elucidating the underlying aetiological mechanisms for the formation of isolated oral-facial clefts is the permutation of and possibly sequential interactions in these factors that result in the ultimate occurrence of oral-facial clefts as well as the likelihood that isolated CL and isolated CP have different aetiologies.

In this study, sunshine is consistently shown to be the most significant factor for isolated CL, but the role of sunshine, apart from providing a source of vitamin D, remains unclear. However, UVR as reported by the EPD did not show any correlation with the overall incidence, and the availability of vitamin D per se may not be the obvious explanation. Both NOx and NO at 8 weeks postconception also displayed a significant inverse correlation with isolated CL and isolated CLCP. NOx is produced by the combustion procedure of the vehicular engines and power plants, and includes NO, NO2, and N2O, but the main compound emitted during combustion is NO, a highly reactive free radical and an important biological signaling molecule of multiple physiological functions, including smooth muscle relaxation, 34 immune regulations, and defense mechanisms. 35 The NO is highly lipid soluble with a high diffusion coefficient and long diffusion distance, 29 and can diffuse through the cytoplasm and plasma membrane, 36 so that excessive NO could diffuse into the cell and accumulate in the lipid-enriched plasma membrane. The NO plays important physiological roles in pregnancy, as it can regulate trophoblast activity and is associated with trophoblast cell proliferation in both normal and disease pregnancy. 37 Moreover, in an animal study, NO was found to peak in the decidua and thought to be essential for the maintenance of the cell survival. 30 The NO is also involved in the adjustment of the proper timing of blastocyst implantation and supporting fetal growth. 38 As well, it is protective against infection, but by the same token it can damage tissues, proteins, and DNA. 29 Increased NO concentration through overproduction from the cell, or probably from overexposure, to a level which exceeds the body system’s ability to process it, leads to nitrosative stress, 39 which can alter protein structures and thus the normal function of the cell. 31 Indeed, reactive NO radicals could damage extracellular matrix which is important in regulating cell migration, adhesion, and proliferation, 40 so that excessive exposure to or activities of NO at the precise timing of the formation of the lips and palate during embryonic development could play an important teratogenic role. 19 However, only 1 study suggested a relationship between NO with congenital structural anomalies, in which NO was shown to be important for the normal axial development in the chicken embryos. 41

Although our findings contrasted with that reported from Taiwan, 33 where the association with O3 was found, these 2 studies have both pointed to the role of environmental factors in the occurrence of oral-facial clefts, which warrants further scrutiny. There is literature on the relationship between ambient air pollutants with congenital anomalies, for instance, increased exposure to CO, SO2, NO2, and PM10 were positively correlated with increased risk of Tetralogy of Fallot. 28 The risk of atrial septal defect was associated with increased PM10 exposure 42 but negatively with CO concentration. 42 In contrast, the risk of ventricular septal defect was associated with CO concentration 43 but inversely correlated with ambient O3 and SO2 levels. 42 In these studies, however, the role of sunshine was not examined.

In conclusion, we have demonstrated that in a small city without significant variations in racial and environmental factors, the seasonality in the incidence of oral-facial clefts by date-of-conception was significantly and inversely correlated with the levels of sunshine in the first trimester, and the level of nitrogen oxides at around 8 weeks postconception, and the effect appeared to be most important on clefts involving the lip. Further ecological studies are warranted to delineate the multifactorial and sequential involvement of the environmental factors in the occurrence of oral-facial clefts in order to minimize the unnecessary fetal loss from pregnancy termination for this group of nonlethal abnormalities.

fn.p: The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
